content:
The game's over. I've spoilered this post to avoid spoiling the result for people who want to read it from the start, but here's the player list, and how they died:

Spoiler: Flips
Nikanor (Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 1)
implosion (Vanilla Townie, died Night 1)
vijay2vasandani (Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 2)
havingfitz Shotty to the Body (JOAT (Cop*1, Neighbourizer*1), died Night 2)
Code_X (Mafia Goon, lynched Day 3)
Oso (Town Mason, died Night 3)
Robbnva (Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 4)
splitfarvle (Town Mason, died Night 4)
Nero Cain WorstMafiaPlayerEver (Mafia Goon, lynched Day 5)
triangle123 (Vanilla Townie, died Night 6)
YYR gorckat (Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 6)
Tierce ConfidAnon (Vanilla Townie, endgamed Day 6)
zoraster (Mafia Goon, survived)

Rules

Fair play
1. All sitewide rules apply.
2. Play to win. It's more fun to win fairly than if your opponents throw the game.
3. Don't quote things that aren't public knowledge, or make use of the exact wording or metadata like timestamps of private communication. (It's OK to paraphrase the meaning. Just not to use things like wording as evidence that you're not faking the communication.)
4. Don't use hidden or small text, cryptography, or provable randomness. (Breadcrumbs are OK.)
5. Until this game is over, don't discuss it anywhere but this thread, or other locations I specifically allow you to discuss it in. If I send you a link to a place where you can discuss the game privately, keep that link secret until the game is over. (And if someone tries to contact you about this game and they shouldn't be doing so, let me or a list mod know immediately.)
6. Dead players (i.e. players who have been lynched or killed) shouldn't post (not here, nor in places their role PM allows them to, nor in unrelated areas). I will create a QuickTopic that dead players can use to discuss the game if they wish, and give the link to players when they die.
7. Don't pretend to break a rule, even if you aren't actually breaking another rule. (For instance, you can't post your role PM publicly; so don't post a fake role PM publicly either.)
8. Please try to stay civil. It's not fun having a game thread full of insults and personal attacks.
9. Don't try to gain an advantage from rulebreaking, either yours or another player's. (This doesn't mean you shouldn't report it if you see it happens; just don't try to use it as a weapon.) If players break rules, I will try to resolve the situation in a way that preserves the balance of the game. (This means that if you're trying to use a breaking strategy that depends on deliberately getting modkilled, don't expect it to work.)
10. Don't pretend to take day actions you can't actually take. That is, don't vote unless you can vote, don't attempt to daykill someone unless your role actually allows you to daykill someone, etc.

Administrative
11. Day deadlines will be two weeks long. Night deadlines will be 72 hours long. I will let you know the deadlines in each vote count.
12. If players need to be replaced, deadlines will be extended accordingly; days will not end due to deadlines within 72 hours of a player replacing in, nor nights within 24 hours of a player replacing in.
13. If you find you don't have enough time to play the game, let me know and I'll try to find a replacement. (But that makes the game worse for everyone, so try to avoid doing that.)
14. If you want to replace into this game, let me know by PM. In an ideal world, nobody would ever replace out and your request would be pointless, but in practice it's pretty rare for that to actually happen. I'll let you know when a slot becomes free.
15. If you don't post for 72 hours, you will be prodded; if you don't respond to a prod by posting in the thread within 48 hours, are prodded twice in a game day, or are prodded three times overall, I will begin looking for a replacement, and you will be replaced out when I find one, unless you post in the thread before I find one.
16. If the number of players voting for a player doesn't match the number of votes on that player, I will make that clear in the vote count. If you see a discrepancy without an obvious sign that it's deliberate, it's an accident; please let me know so that I can fix the vote count.
17. Your role PM requires you to confirm that you're willing to play when the game starts. The game will start when 80% or more of the player list (for a 13 player game, that's 11 players) have confirmed.
18. If you are required to take an action, but don't submit one, the moderator will choose your targets for you randomly.
19. Should something go wrong, please contact me or a list mod. If I should need to be replaced for any reason, Papa Zito knows where to find details of the setup, and can appoint a backup mod.

Setup
20. This game will start with a day phase, then alternate between night and day phases until the game ends.
21. During day phases, each player can vote to lynch themself or another player, or to no-lynch. You can change or retract your vote as often as you like, but can only have one vote out at a time. Votes will be reset at the start of each day.
22. I don't require players to unvote; voting will implicitly remove any previous vote you might have. However, consider explicitly unvoting anyway as a courtesy to the other players.
23. To vote, I recommend using the [vo​te][/vote] tags, which look like this:VOTE: callforjudgement. (There is a similar tag for unvoting.) I will accept anything that I notice that looks like a vote, though. (If you're going to boldvote, make life easier for people by putting it on a line of its own.)
24. Day will end when a majority of players (that is, more than half) are voting for the same person. That player will be lynched and removed from the game, no longer counting as alive. Then a night phase will start.
25. Day will also end at deadline, or if half or more of the players are voting for No Lynch. In these circumstances, nobody will be lynched, but a night phase will start anyway.
26. During a night phase, this thread will be locked, and players who can take actions overnight can take them by PMing me with the action they want to take. (Anti-town players who have a QuickTopic to communicate in can alternatively take night actions by posting them in bold in their QuickTopic.) All night actions will be resolved simultaneously at the end of the night, using Natural Action Resolution (in the usual case where there are no conflicts between actions, this means resolving each action after actions that affect it). Note that killing a player does not prevent them taking actions that night. Night phases end at deadline.
27. As a Mini Normal game, the exact details of this game's setup are not public. However, you do know the following facts about the setup:
  • At least 12 of the 13 players have an explicitly normal role, from the following list: Vanilla Townie, Sane Cop, Doctor, Vigilante, Roleblocker, Mason, Innocent Child, Jailkeeper, Tracker, Watcher, Gunsmith, Miller, Bodyguard, Role Cop, Doublevoter, Hider, Neighbor, Neighborizer, Jack of All Trades, Serial Killer, Mafia Goon, Mafia Traitor, Mafia Godfather, Mafia Framer, Mafia-aligned versions of above roles, possibly with an explicitly normal modifier: Even/Odd Night, Non-Consecutive Night, X-Shot, Bulletproof, Neighbor, Compulsive, Macho, Weak, Backup (with or without primary role present). It is possible that all 13 players have a role on this list; it is also possible that the 13th player has some other role.
  • There are either 1 or 2 anti-town factions consisting of 2 or more players; and either 0 or 1 anti-town factions consisting of a single player.
  • The only possible win conditions are the Town, Mafia/Werewolf, Traitor, and Serial Killer win conditions. (So no jesters, lynchers, survivors, or cults.)
  • At least 1 player will get the Vanilla Townie role PM, which looks like this (with the name changed):
    Welcome, callforjudgement. You are a Vanilla Townie.

    During the day, you may discuss the game with the other players in the game thread.

    You have no special abilities.

    You are aligned with the town. You win when all living players are aligned with the town, even if you are dead yourself.

    Confirm by PMing a summary of your role to callforjudgement.
28. When a player dies, details of their role, alignment, and any modifiers will be posted in-thread.

(As a Normal game, flavour has no effect on the game.)

After hours of eating and some rather good wine, the party was in full swing. The light was fading; but a massive snowstorm had whipped up outside, making nobody inclined to leave. They had grown tired of talk, and bored of cards, but there was still time to have fun. So they went down to the parlour, agreed some rules, shuffled up a deck to randomize the roles, and sat down for a friendly game of Mafia.

Such a pity that not all of them were so friendly…

Sorry about the delay starting, I'm having technical problems unlocking the thread. Once it's unlocked, I'll change the deadline based on the time the thread actually gets unlocked…

…and we're off. These mod tools need to come with instructions :)
Good morning, friends

Afternoon!

split wrote:How is connection hunting on day one bad?

Vi said it best:
Beginner's Guide wrote:Do not fool yourself into thinking you can call the scumteam, especially before anyone has flipped scum. Don't bother with trying to draw connections between players until one of them is dead. It's tempting! but futile.

The most important word here is "futile." Yes, you might wind up calling a pair of scum through a connection. But the odds of that are extremely low. There'll be more information on later days, so for now, we should just focus on people that we find scummy and not on connections. It's much, MUCH more difficult to identify a scummy connection on day one than it is to identify a scummy person. To prove that, suppose you're trying to identify a scummy person. Let's assume that you're town and that there are 13 total players, so 12 players other than you. Let's also assume 3 scum. Then you have a 25% chance of being right on any given player being scum. Now, consider a connection between two players. There are 11 + 10 + 9 + ... + 1 total possible connections amongst other players, or 66. Exactly 3 of those connections are between scum (scum A - scum B, scum A - scum C, scum B - scum C). So the probability that your connection will be right is 3/66 or 1/22, much lower than 1/4. More than that, you can relatively easily look at every single player in the game to find which ones are scummy - you can't easily look at every single connection in the game because there are so damn many of them. On later days, that isn't as true, however, because there will be flipped scum (and it's worth looking at their connections) and flipped town (who we won't spend as much time looking at). But most importantly is simply the fact that you're almost always going to be wrong on some of your reads, and connection hunting without flips assumes way too much about how good you are at reading people. Sorry if you don't want a lesson, but you asked...

Robbnva wrote:P. edit actually the beauty of that comment condemns you either way.

Let's try another way of looking at that, really quick. Using formal logic.
Nikanor can't be both town and scum. If I'm scum, then my interaction towards nikanor MUST be exactly one out of S-->S or S-->T. If I' town, then both of the lines of reasoning must be unsound (because they lead to false conclusions). So, let's assume for a moment that I'm scum.
This means that at least one of those two lines of reasoning must be unsound. It could theoretically, even though i'm scum, be that both of them are unsound (i'll explain why if you want, in short, a false argument can lead to a true conclusion). However, let's assume for a minute that one line of reasoning is valid and sound.
Now, we KNOW that one of those two lines of reasoning is unsound. Therefore, either the "if nik flips scum then implo is scum" reasoning is flawed, or the "if nik flips town then implo is scum" reasoning is flawed. That's the definition of an unsound argument. Suppose that the first one is flawed. Then if nik flips scum, i can't be scum because of that reasoning. Suppose the second is flawed. Then if nik flips town, i can't be scum because of that reasoning.

Even before nikanor flips, we KNOW, from a neutral point of view, that one of those lines of reasoning must be invalid. Now, as soon as Nikanor flips, anyone who wants to push on me can just say "well, now we know which one is valid." That violates logical principles - seeing as we know RIGHT NOW that one of them must be unsound, we (meaning you) should be required to choose only one of them, seeing as adopting flawed arguments is logically impermissible.

Let's take an analogy. A man is a suspect in two murder cases - however, the murders took place at exactly the same time in two very far-apart locations. Therefore, the man can't have committed both of them. Saying "well, we'll just imprison him for whichever murder is solved second" is logically unacceptable. This should be for obvious reasons.

Let's further the analogy. A man is suspected of having carried out 1000 different murder cases - however, the murders took place at exactly the same time in 1000 very far-apart locations. The man can't have committed more than one of them. Saying "the man committed whichever murder is solved last" is, as before, logically unacceptable. This analogy should make that a little clearer. It's kind of like the monty hall dilemma. Sort of. Or maybe I just want it to be. In short, you know already that one of those lines of reasoning is flawed - waiting to see which one is eliminated as impossible doesn't automatically make the other one valid, and i'm damn sure that you and/or others will say that it does. If nik flips town, you'll just say "oh well here's robb's reasoning for why implo is scum if nik flips town, i guess that was right." Doing this is intellectually dishonest, because you know that you're pushing a flawed argument.

Robb wrote:everyone is guilty until proven innocent

Oh boy, i get to write a short essay on why you're wrong!
Spoiler: said essay
Point one: the beginning of the game. Let's say that the game hasn't started yet. Based on the logic of "everyone is guilty until proven innocent," you should have fossed everyone before they posted. This, obviously, is contradictory, because there is no way in hell that everyone is scum. A much more internally consistent outlook that's still consistent with the "i think towntells are rare" sentiment would be something like vollkan used to do - he listed everyone in the game as having a number. Everyone started at 50. 100 meant confirmed scum, 0 meant confirmed town. Any time someone scumtold, he'd give them points. Any time someone towntold, he'd lower their score. He also made a note that he tended to give more points than he took away - which he did. However, guilty until proven innocent is completely ridiculous in this sense.

Point two: mafia is a proofless game. There is never, EVER, proof in mafia. You're a cop with a guilty, you say? Could be framed. Someone claimed scum, you say? They might be a vengeful townie. You watched someone who claimed VT visit the nightkill, you say? There could be some new role in the game that can cause false positives on tracker/watcher reports. Point is, no one will EVER be proven innocent. Now, i know that what you really mean is "guilty until they've towntold." This is also fallacious - not all townies will towntell at all, and those that do won't always towntell in ways that everyone sees. We'll just lynch anyone who doesn't towntell, you say? Well, some of those people will be town. Perhaps the majority. Perhaps enough that lynching all of them will give the mafia a majority. Point here is, you can't say that people have to towntell to be town. It's simply inconsistent with empirical reality.

Point three (most important, probably): practicality. There are several goals of being a townie. One of those goals is, of course, to scumhunt properly. What is scumhunting properly? Well, I'd argue that the goal is to have as many correct reads as possible and as few incorrect reads as possible. To that end, having significantly more scumreads than there can potentially be scum in the game is fallacious. Sure, you could counter-argue and say that the only read that's important is the one that you're currently pushing on to get lynched. Of course, you can't argue this, because you've pushed heavily on about 5 different people throughout today and changed your opinion on a dime over and over. But regardless, it's anti-town to have incorrect reads. Reads influence people. Influencing people to have false opinions is patently antitown. I'm not saying that you should always have EXACTLY 3 scumreads and EXACTLY 10 townreads - but when you have stated scumreads on 2/3 of the people that could be scum from your point of view... you get the point.

I'm going to make this post quick because yesterday and today are quite busy days for me, but I just want to catch up on everything I've missed.

In the beginning of the game, Robbnva stood out as one of my stronger town reads, and now I feel rather conflicted about him. On the one hand, some people have made good points about the fact that his vote has been flopping all over the place and preventing lynches from occurring, and he has been making some claims about people that border dangerously on misrepresentation and misquoting/taking quotes out of context.

However, what stops me from having him as a scum read is that sometimes vote hopping isn't necessarily an indication of scum behavior. Somewhat indecisive town (as Robbnva appears to be, judging from his rather lengthy list of scum reads - and this isn't a bad thing, necessarily) will always tend to be rethinking their votes, especially in light of new information, and so many vote changes suggests that the person casting the votes is actively thinking and changing opinions about who should be the right lynch. Scum doesn't really change opinions; town do because they're the ones attempting to determine who is scum and who is not.

Furthermore, I can't really see a scum motivation for his vigilante counterclaim. That would be an enormously risky move for scum to pull because it can be so easily proven or contradicted based on the night kills. Oso mentioned something about how Robbnva could say he's a one-shot vig, but somewhere (I forget where at the moment) Robbnva said something along the lines of "people would notice something suspicious if there was only one nightkill every night" (not a quote, just paraphrasing), which precludes the possibility of him later claiming one-shot vig.

For now, I still consider Robbnva town but he's closer to the scum side of the spectrum than he was before. Either way, he definitely is not a good lynch for Day 1 because claimed power roles, particularly in light of other prospects, are generally not the way to go here. A Nik or Vijay lynch is the best option right now, in my opinion, especially the former.

The party was in full swing, and the players in the parlour were mostly having fun, pointing out their accusations with their fingers and yelling out cases. The occasional insult too; things were getting somewhat heated. But eventually, the fingers swung round to point at Nikanor. As the seventh finger started pointing, suddenly, Nikanor dropped dead. Nobody quite believed it at first, and then they tried first aid, but his heart had stopped beating, and he wasn't breathing, and in the end they gave up. Someone tried to phone for an ambulence, but the phone lines weren't working; they must have been damaged in the snowstorm. In the end, they dumped his body outside in the snow, where it would be preserved until a post-mortem could be carried out. Nobody felt much like playing after that, so they all went off upstairs to bed for the night.

As irrelevant as it seemed, though, people were still wondering if, at least, he was scum. So they looked at the card he was holding…

Nikanor has been lynched. He was a Vanilla Townie.
It is now Night 1. Please get any night actions in to me, town via PM and anti-town players via PM or QuickTopic, within the next 72 hours.

Night deadline is Saturday 26 May at 18:32 UTC. (Automatic countdown: (expired on 2012-05-26 18:32:00))

The night would not last long. Some of the guests only managed to catch a quick hour of troubled sleep, when everyone was woken by a piercing scream. And clearly, some of them had not slept at all, although it was not obviously clear who. The door to everyone's bedroom was locked, but someone had "thoughtfully" provided megaphones. And there were those remote controls that people use for voting during conferences. It wasn't at all hard to guess what people were supposed to vote on. Someone wanted the game to continue.

It soon became apparent who was missing. Based on who was and wasn't speaking, implosion must have died overnight. And, of course, you can always recognise a vanilla townie by their scream.

Vijay is not exactly the best player to have around and I'm not a fan of his self-proclaimed village idiot actions, but he has not done anything to really make me suspect he's scum. I'm not comfortable using a lynch on him unless the deadline is too close and we don't have any other valid choices. I did decide to take another look at Code_X, though.

Code_X has been a tentative town read of mine for much of the game, but I reread his iso more closely than I did before. Most people who have made cases on him called his original catch-up post scummy because it consisted of mostly summary, and I still maintain that I don't think the fact that he summarized is suspicious. The part he put in spoilers seemed primarily to serve as his personal notes as he read, and I generally take similar notes on a Word document while I read and they do tend to be almost all summary. I also don't find his vote on Nikanor suspicious because he did point out a few scummy facets of Nikanor's play in his catch-up and his reasoning seemed okay there.

However, what does jump out to me now that I didn't notice before is that he had a lot of evidence on Nik, which is why it makes sense for him to say Nik is his top scum read, but then he wrote that Nik is "closely followed by Split". But going back to the catch-up portion of his post, the only point he makes against Split is that he random-voted a little bit after RVS ended despite the fact that he does make some other points against other people. It'd be different if he had said that Split was one of his scum reads or a weaker read or something of that nature, but he singled out Split and implied that he's a strong scum read.

Another thing I noticed is something I believe Nikanor had pointed out at some point, but I hadn't been following his case on Code_X too closely because I was so sure Nik was scum. In a response to Nik, Code_X had written the following:

Code_X wrote:Your barking completely up the wrong tree and your wishy-washy early style of cautious play and trying to avoid confontation has turned into an ultra-aggressive style completely the opposite in the hope of saving your own skin.


The phrase "barking up the wrong tree" would imply that Nikanor is town. This is a small point and certainly not the basis for my changed read on Code_X but this does feel like a minor scumslip to me.

What also strikes me as scummy is the fact that Code_X tunneled very hard on Nikanor for much of Day 1 without it actually feeling like tunneling. By this I mean that almost all his posts centered around attacks on Nikanor and he had minimal commentary on other players.

Tunneling isn't by itself an indication of alignment, but generally when town chooses to tunnel, it's because they're truly convinced that their target is scum, and that tends to be obvious from their posts through aggression or through constantly bringing up new points against the person they think is scum. But Code_X was primarily defending himself from Nikanor and his posts did not really have the aggression typically seen in tunneling cases. Instead, it feels like he decided to stay slightly in the background without showing much of a conscious effort at scumhunting. Even his initial case on Nikanor consisted mainly of points that other people had made.

He did not comment much on other players, and when he did, the cases he outlined were fairly weak and unsupported. The switch of his vote onto WMPE felt a bit random and out of nowhere, but what I really found strange was that after he re-affirmed that he doesn't find Vijay scummy, he made post #605 where he very strongly implied that Vijay is scum and deserving of a lynch.

The more I think about this, the more certain I am that Nero is actually town. My main reasons for finding him scum before were that he has been a lackluster participant in the game and that he'd blatantly sheeped Robbnva with his earlier vote on Tierce, but his previous lack of effort is actually a null tell. What's to say he's lazy scum instead of lazy town? Furthermore, he changed from voting Tierce to voting me, which surprised me because if you're scum and in a day approaching deadline quickly, chances are that you'll want to be rushing a lynch. So if you're rushing a lynch, you'd most likely try to go after someone who's already racked up some votes or is already showing potential as a lynch candidate - you don't try to go after someone who no one else has expressed interest in lynching. Nero's case on me, then, was a genuine effort at scumhunting.

As for my vote on Tierce, I think it's fairly clear that Tierce and Robbnva are of opposing alignments, so lynching one gives information as to the other. If Robbnva is scum, the team is likely to be Robbnva and Nero. If Tierce is scum, it's likely to be Tierce and YYR. When I was thinking about this, my first instinct was to vote for Robbnva, but I decided to do a re-read of both their ISOs before making a hasty decision.

I've had a steady town read on Robbnva for much of the early part of the game, and my read on him only started flip-flopping when I was thinking from the perspective of Nero as scum. But now that I'm realizing Nero is more likely to be town, I don't really see Robbnva as that scummy. I've always had a pretty fixed idea of Tierce as town, but certain aspects of her play stuck out to me when I was re-reading her ISO, and I may have been too close-minded to notice them before. Her sudden switch onto Vijay was one of these. I know she did explain this in one of her posts, but something about it strikes me as contrived.

I also feel like I may have been wrong in discounting the idea of the Code_X wagon being a bus because something Tierce said is standing out to me: her repeated arguments about how bad the havingfitz kill was. This argument is, of course, particularly WIFOM-y, but the way she repeated it two or three times is somewhat odd. I think it's quite possible that she purposely did a bad kill, sacrificing an already scummy member of her scum team, in order to make herself look townier, and this idea is supported by the fact that she's stated that she's seen an experienced player do the same tactic effectively.

I've been thinking about this for a while and keep second-guessing myself, but for now, this is where I want my vote.
Actually, if Tierce is scum, I'm not so sure about a Tierce/YYR scumteam. But that's irrelevant right now.

    The next time he really brings up YYR is to say he (Nero) is "really think' YYR is scum" (1575, then he pushes a triangle/YYR/code scum team (1577). Then Tierce becomes Nero's first choice, YYR second (1685)
  • YYR-Triangle
    Opening statement on Triangle is “no read” (1186). “I haven’t read Triangle.” (1284). Mentions Triangle in an offhand way to someone else (1302). At some point there, Triangle becomes the “only firm town read” YYR has. (1592). Again talks about Triangle in third person (not directed at Triangle) calling him obvtown (1650).
    Triangle has a town read on YYR (1339, about 300 posts after YYR joins up). Triangle says that the scum team is likely Tierce and YYR if it’s Tiercescum (1594) in the same post with a Tierce vote. Then backs away from that the next post. Next interaction was today.
    This worries me a little bit as Triangle and YYR have virtually no interaction with each other directly. Then again, I don’t really recall interacting with Triangle myself. Mostly I just think if YYR and Triangle were buddies, they probably would do more to at least seem like they were interacting. As it is, they kind of just leave each other alone. My gut says no to this pairing.
  • YYR-Tierce
    YYR starts off with a pretty manufactured interaction with Tierce (1186 etc.) with some questions back and forth. Then a very “buddy buddy” kind of thing with YYR saying “Tierce stealin’ my hammer” (1211). Then he comes out with a little stronger against Tierce saying “what’s the town motivation for this?” to Tierce asking about the neighborizer power (1268). YYR is later “worried by Tierce” but then the next time he mentions Tierce he says “[Tierce] has done a good job explaining things” (1337. More buddy buddy activity from YYR in Post 1440 (“Abort Tierce! Abort!”)

    Then things get interesting. He says that a Tierce lynch is better than a Nero lynch (as mentioned in the Nero section), but has Robbnva ahead of Tierce in scumminess (1592). But then he starts setting up a IF… THEN… scenario with Robb and Tierce. I.e. “If Robb is scum, Tierce isn’t.”
    Tierce’s mentions of YYR are somewhat similar. For example, Post 1269 is sort of a buddying up type of thing where she comments on something he said, but doesn’t really bring any heat. The next YYR mention is one where she calls YYR town along with Triangle (1308). The next is basically a place where she skirmishes with Robbnva about whether YYR and Triangle are town (since Robbnva was of the firm belief that the setup was 12 scum and 1 town). Then she defends Robb’s claim that YYR and triangle were lurking. More “YYR is town” here. Then Tierce makes a pretty broad meta based post about YYR (1514).


  • Nero-Triangle
    Nero makes a comment about triangle being the last scum with conftown split. Then Nero asks YYR why YYR never said Triangle was town before. As of this point, he hasn’t addressed anything to Triangle all game. In fact other than a list that… I don’t even know what it was supposed to mean (1642) Nero doesn’t even try to address Triangle except as a way to attack YYR.
    First time Triangle brings up Nero is to vote him because of “Process of Elimination.” (1331) and a really tiny ISO. At this point, Triangle says that Nero is the only one he’s comfortable lynching. Says that Nero’s town claim may not actually make him town. At this point, Triangle goes pretty hard after Nero. Then triangle rethinks his stance on Nero, and thinks Nero is town (1594). After this point, Nero doesn’t really come up.
  • Nero-Tierce
    Tierce starts off having only content by quoting Nero when he was quoted himself. While voting Robbnva, she believes the final scum is within me and Nero and “would find it hilarious if Code cleared both his teammates” (1308). She goes for snark when she asks Robbnva about his “scumbuddy Nero” (1311). But then she says she doesn’t want to lynch Nero today, she wants to lynch Robbnva (1322). Then she moves to put Nero at L-1 (1341). She asks Nero to claim at 1357, he does so, then she immediately moves her vote to Robbnva at 1363. Next she agrees with Triangle that his towntell (where he includes splitfarvle in the possible scum) is “nagging her.” (1402). Haven't done Triangle-Tierce yet, but I'm running out of time before work, and I think I should post this and come back to T&T.

These are the pairings that seem most likely to me in order:
1. YYR-Nero: This is my biggest pairing read. These two barely mention each other at first (besides YYR saying he just doesn't have much n Nero), but more importantly, when both mention the other it's usually to put them in the "He's Scummy but Less Scummy than Other People" category. This looks to be a pretty classic distancing attempt. They don't want each other to be lynched but they also want to be seen as being in conflict with each other. Which... they never really are.
2. YYR-Tierce: YYR-Tierce makes sense to me, but it worries me some that YYR has recently been riding the Tierce lynch pretty hard. In 5p lylo, I’d really expect scum to go for the win here. Yesterday would have been the more obvious bus day. It’s complicated by the fact that Tierce and Robb were in a virtual 1v1 situation and a bus might be “called for” here (in the same way CodeX was an obvious lynch), but I don’t think Tierce is anywhere near that level of obvlynch.
3. Nero-Tierce: Before I started this, this was my best guess for a scum pairing. It isn't now, but it remains plausible. It would require Tierce to have heavily distanced from Nero, frequently putting him at L-1 (though always professing a preference for Robb) and then going after him today, although I don't know if she was seriously thinking she'd get the Nero lynch at that point or was just making a point.
4. Nero-Triangle: I remain fairly convinced of Triangle-town, but of the two triangle pairings I've looked at so far, this one is the more compelling. But even so, the reversal of his opinion on Nero, though perhaps well timed to get a Robb or Tierce lynch, doesn't seem like something Triangle would do as scum.
5. YYR-Triangle: Using my WIFOMy reasoning I gave above, I don't think this pairing makes sense as neither has tried in the slightest to distance themselves from each other. The only time that it was plausible was when Triangle said that if Tiercescum then YYRscum, but then backs away from it... if you're distancing, why not leave that intact?

Still need time to digest this (as well as, for the sake of completeness, do Triangle-Tierce... maybe it turns up something surprising), but this was actually kind of helpful for me to add some structure. Hopefully it's helpful to others.

Biggest takeaway now: It makes me very wary of a Tierce lynch today.

From a mod's point of view, the big advantage of masons in a game is that they limit the power of the scum NK. Not only do they have to choose between good and confirmed, they also have to choose between confirmed players and probable power roles. In post 1866, zoraster wrote:Good job modding, CFJ. The only big suggestion was the one I made via PM: remove the replacement extends day deadline indefinitely. It SUCKS to be scum and plan your play so that the deadline will run up against you and make a quick lynch happen without as many consequences and then end up having it extended forever.

Fwiw, I think deadline extensions are generally scumsided, and were in particular this game because they pretty much just lead to more pointless town infighting. Town certainly didn't make good use of them.

And I'm more focused on ensuring that V/LAs or flaking don't end deciding the game, which can happen with pretty much any other rule. (I remember being forced to lynch a particular player in a newbie game, because nobody else was lynchable because of flaking. I was scum and they were town, so I didn't massively care, but it must have sucked for the other players.)

Well, we're having a discussion right now (sort of a very slow discussion, but nevertheless) in the review group that suggests we may have become too complacent in how much the move to 13p from 12p altered the game in favor of town. The total win rates for scum have inched their way up to 60%, so we're going to have to start reevaluating. In any event, I don't think it was outrageously unbalanced or anything. More like every game is going to be scum or townsided to some extent (almost any game anyway), and it's just a matter of identifying which it was -- though the result isn't about that.

And I think if the game becomes unplayable, sure, call a halt to the game, put it on pause or even extend the deadline. But one replacement shouldn't extend the deadline like it did multiple times. I'm not sure it matters whether it was pro town or scum, it's extremely frustrating for scum.
